title.narrative: Emergency mobile Nutrition for IDPs and selected far to reach areas in Oromia Region, Guji Zone, Gumi Eldalo and Liben Woredas

description.narrative:
Mercy Corps (MC) proposes to continue the critical nutrition services provided for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and host communities in Guji zone, Liben and Gumi Eldalo woredas to address the urgent needs of conflict induced displaced people and host communities who do not have access to primary health care services. The number of IDPs in Gumi Eldalo and Liben woredas of Guji Zone is growing day by day due to the ongoing conflict around the border of Oromia and Somali Region.
The overall objective of this project is to contribute to the reduction of morbidity and mortality linked to malnutrition, and increase access to primary health care services for the IDPs and host communities in the proposed target woredas. Diarrhea, pneumonia, malaria, upper respiratory tract infection and malnutrition are the main morbidities mostly affecting children within these communities and leads to morbidity if not treated in timely manner.
The proposed six month project will address acute malnutrition in children under 5 years of age (CU5) and pregnant and lactating women (PLW) using the Community Based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) and Infant and Young Child Feeding in Emergencies (IYCF-E) approaches, as well as providing Mobile Health Service (MHS) to improve access to basic primary health care services. Using a comprehensive package approach, the proposed project will also promote hand washing at critical moments and environmental sanitation to mitigate potential outbreaks of water borne diseases, including Acute Watery Diarrhea (AWD).
MC aims to address both moderate and severe acute malnutrition and reach 13,673 beneficiaries (CU5 and PLW) by implementing the full CMAM continuum of care, which includes community mobilization Outpatient Therapeutic Program (OTP) Stabilization Center (SC) and Targeted Supplementary Feeding Program (TSFP). The TSFP program will rely on the TSFP commodity availability pipeline from WFP. Every admitted beneficiary will receive targeted counseling on Maternal Infant and Young Child Nutrition (MIYCN) emphasizing infant and young child feeding (IYCF) and personal and household level hygiene. Mobile Health Nutrition Teams (MHNTs) will be deployed to reach the IDP camps and other hard to reach areas in both woredas by providing primary health care services including vaccinations and antenatal care.
The intervention comprises three project outcomes:
1. Nutrition – Community Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM)
Outcome 1: Improved nutrition capacity to manage Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), with and without complications, using Community-Based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) Outcome 2: Improved capacity to manage moderate malnutrition (MAM) among children 6 – 59 months, pregnant women and lactating mothers with children less than 6 months old Outcome 3: Increased awareness of community members on the importance of optimal infant and young child feeding and caring practices and other nutrition related topics, as well as hygiene-related behaviors
